bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, May 4, 1949

div1.p: Hench thanks Lyons for her praise of his arthritis research. He has not progressed far on his Reed book, but finds the yellow fever research a wonderful hobby and plans to finish the book.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, May 4, 1949
div1.opener:
May 4, 1949
Miss Bertha L. Lyons
Hall of Fame
New York University
1 Madison Avenue
New York, 10, New York
Dear Miss Lyons:
div1.p:
How nice of you to write me about our work. Since it was announced, we have
been inundated with letters but a few stand out and have given me unusual
pleasure and yours is certainly one of those. We are not on home plate yet
but we hope we are somewhere near second base and seven months ago we didn't
even know where the playing field was.

I wish I could report that I am pretty far along on the Reed book
but actually I am not. It was my pleasant fate to have my hobby rudely
interrupted by this work which may be of so much value; certainly of more
value than a work on medical history. Nevertheless, I am continuing my
work on the yellow fever story as it is a wonderful hobby which affords me
great relaxation and pleasure and I certainly will finish it. That is a
strong promise.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
